timeline.bodyText: Not a big fan of watchers, it's slightly different from the hot reload approach. @stuartwdouglas WDYT?
timeline.author: cescoffier

replies.bodyText: it's actively watching for file changes. That's to enable users to use the changes right away in their code (without doing a request to the app first).

replies.bodyText: We don't want to use the normal hot reload approach here. Otherwise you need to reload your browser for the generated source code to be generated, go back to your IDE to actually use the generated source, then back to your browser to see the changes.

timeline.bodyText:
Please add a single line of JavaDoc explaining the purpose of this mojo.
Is there any reason against adding threadSafe = true?
timeline.author: ppalaga

replies.bodyText: does it mark a plugin safe to run in parallel with building other modules?
replies.author: michalszynkiewicz

replies.bodyText:
https://maven.apache.org/developers/mojo-api-specification.html

Marks this mojo as being thread-safe, i.e. the mojo safely supports concurrent execution during parallel builds. Mojos without this annotation will make Maven output a warning when used during a parallel build session. The short-hand notation @threadsafe without a tag value is equivalent to @threadsafe true. Since Maven 3.0.
replies.author: ppalaga
